p: Social changes, and/or increased human mobility [ 3], and the onset of urbanization in colonial Africa [ 27] have also been invoked as explanations for HIV emergence. We proposed that a high frequency of genital ulcer diseases (GUD), such as syphilis, chancroid, and lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), a result of those social changes, and possibly also a relatively low frequency of male circumcision, in nascent colonial cities may have been the triggers of initial HIV transmission and adaptation to humans [ 16]. GUD induced genital ulcers can dramatically increase HIV transmission [ 16, 36, 37], and our work suggests that the high prevalence of these diseases might have provided crucial “help” for the initial spread of the virus.
